content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of fibro-adipose tissue. Within this tissue, there are at least five well-defined, basophilic (dark purple) nodules of varying sizes, which are consistent with lymph nodes. My initial impression is that this is a lymph node dissection, and my primary task is to systematically examine each of these lymph nodes for evidence of metastatic cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, it is crucial to examine every piece of tissue submitted, not just the large, obvious lymph nodes. The area highlighted by the green box contains a smaller, less-defined cluster of basophilic cells. While not as prominent as the larger nodes, this could represent a small, partially replaced lymph node, a tumor deposit within the fat, or lymphovascular invasion. Its subtle appearance makes it a high-priority area for high-magnification review to rule out malignancy. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. After assessing the obvious, large lymph nodes, a thorough pathologist would systematically scan the entire slide, including the intervening adipose tissue and the edges of all tissue fragments. The area marked by the green box is a small, somewhat inconspicuous speck at the periphery. I would zoom into this area because even tiny basophilic clusters can represent significant findings, such as: 1) a small tumor deposit (TD) in the fat, which is important for staging, 2) lymphovascular invasion (LVI), or 3) a fragment of a larger positive lymph node that broke off during processing. It is crucial to investigate all such subtle abnormalities. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the protocol for staging colorectal cancer requires the meticulous examination of all recovered lymph nodes for metastasis. The green box is placed over one of the larger and more cellular-appearing lymph nodes on the slide. I would zoom into this area as part of a systematic review of every lymph node to assess its architecture and cellular composition to either identify or rule out the presence of metastatic cancer cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is one of the largest and most abnormal-appearing lymph nodes on the slide. Its dense, solid, and dark appearance suggests effacement of the normal lymph node architecture by a non-lymphoid process. This is a classic presentation for a lymph node replaced by metastatic tumor, and high-power examination is necessary to confirm the presence and nature of the malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to identify and examine every lymph node present in the specimen to determine the N stage. The green box is centered on one of the smaller, discrete basophilic nodules located at the bottom of the slide. Although some other nodes are more obviously positive for metastasis even at low power, a complete and accurate staging requires the careful high-magnification examination of all identified nodes, including the smaller or less suspicious-looking ones. This is simply the next lymph node in my systematic review of the slide. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because I am systematically scanning all the provided tissue, not just the obvious lymph nodes. This particular area is within the pericolic fat, and the faint, elongated pink structure is suspicious for a blood vessel. It is crucial to examine such vessels carefully for the presence of extramural vascular invasion (EMVI), which is the invasion of tumor cells into veins beyond the bowel wall. Finding EMVI is a significant adverse prognostic factor and is essential for accurate staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to systematically examine every piece of tissue to identify all lymph nodes and any potential tumor deposits. The area highlighted by the green box is a small, somewhat subtle basophilic focus in the upper left quadrant of the slide. While not as large or obvious as the other nodes, it must be carefully examined to determine if it is a small lymph node, a fragment of a lymph node, or a satellite tumor deposit in the fat (pN1c). This is the first potential lymph node encountered in a systematic scan starting from the top-left, and its small size necessitates high-power evaluation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in view, I can see multiple aggregates of lymphoid tissue (the dense, dark purple cells). However, intermingled with these lymphocytes and infiltrating the surrounding adipose tissue are clusters and nests of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger, have more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and enlarged, irregular nuclei. They are forming back-to-back glandular structures. My impression is that this is a lymph node that has been infiltrated by metastatic adenocarcinoma. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 2. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a small, cohesive cluster of atypical epithelial cells. The cells have large, hyperchromatic (darkly stained), and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours. They are arranged in a disorganized manner, suggestive of a poorly formed gland. These cells are located within fibrotic stroma and adipose tissue. My impression is that this is a focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. This finding confirms the presence of metastatic disease and would be classified either as part of a positive node if it's connected to one, as lymphovascular invasion, or as a discrete tumor deposit, all of which are critical for accurate cancer staging.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a section of a lymph node that is highly cellular. The architecture is characterized by numerous, crowded lymphoid follicles of varying sizes and shapes, a pattern known as florid follicular hyperplasia. The cells are predominantly small, mature-appearing lymphocytes. There are no definitive features of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant epithelial cells with large nuclei, prominent nucleoli, or significant cytoplasm. My impression of this specific field is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. However, I would need to examine the entire lymph node at high power to be certain.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see a dense, back-to-back proliferation of malignant cells that have completely replaced the normal lymphoid tissue. The cells show significant pleomorphism, with large, hyperchromatic, and irregular nuclei. They are arranged in crowded, poorly formed glandular and cribriform structures. There are also areas of tumor necrosis (the bright pink, amorphous debris). These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node, extensively involved by metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see lymphoid tissue surrounded by adipose tissue. The lymphoid tissue is composed of dense aggregates of small, dark lymphocytes. I can also see the lymph node sinuses, which contain a mix of lymphocytes and some larger histiocytes. I am carefully searching for atypical epithelial cells, either in clusters or forming glands, which would indicate metastasis. In this specific field of view, I do not see any definitive malignant cells. The cells present are consistent with the normal cellular components of a benign, reactive lymph node. My impression of this specific area is negative for metastasis, but I would need to pan across the entire node to make a final determination.
This is ROI 6. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area shows fibro-adipose tissue. On the right, there is a cross-section of a large, thick-walled blood vessel. The focus of interest, however, is a smaller, thinner-walled vessel, consistent with a vein. Within the lumen of this vein, there is a small, distinct cluster of atypical cells with large, dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. This is a tumor embolus. My impression is that this is a clear example of extramural vascular invasion (EMVI). This is a critical finding that must be reported.
This is ROI 7. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area reveals fragments of adipose tissue. The key finding is the presence of pools of pale, eosinophilic, acellular material. This is characteristic of acellular mucin. In the context of a colorectal adenocarcinoma (especially a mucinous type), finding acellular mucin deposits in the perinodal fat is considered a form of metastasis, even in the absence of viable tumor cells. It represents the product of the tumor and is significant for staging (it can be classified as a tumor deposit, pN1c). At the very top left of the high-power view, a small portion of a lymph node with residual lymphoid tissue is also visible. My impression is that this is a tumor deposit consisting of acellular mucin in the perinodal adipose tissue, adjacent to a small lymph node.
